title: Draconid Meteor Shower 2019: How to see shooting stars from the UK tonight
text:

If you’re a fan of stargazing , make sure you mark tonight off in your calendar.

The annual Draconid Meteor Shower will peak this evening, providing you with the perfect opportunity to spot a shooting star in the night sky.

While the Draconid Meteor Shower isn’t the most active shower, if you plan well, there’s a change you could witness it yourself!

Here’s everything you need to know about the Draconids, including what they are, and how you can see them.

When is the Draconid Meteor Shower?

The Draconid Meteor Shower is active between October 6 and 11.

However, this year’s event will peak tonight, so make sure you keep an eye out on the night sky this evening.

(Image: Anadolu)

What time will the meteors be visible?

While many meteor showers are most visible in the early hours of the morning, thankfully there’s no need for an early start if you want to get involved.

The Draconids are most visible just after nightfall, so in the UK, look to the skies from around 18:00 BST tonight.

What are the Draconids?

The Draconid Meteor Shower happens when Earth crosses the orbital path of Comet 21P/Giacobini-Zinner.

Debris from the comet collides with the Earth’s upper atmosphere, where it burns up, producing meteors in the night sky.

(Image: Handout)

How many meteors can we expect?

Unfortunately, the Draconid Meteor Shower isn’t the most active shower, so you’ll need to have a sharp eye to spot a shooting star.

Experts predict that the shower will only produce around five meteors per hour.

When is the next meteor shower?

If you miss the Draconid Meteor Shower, thankfully there’s another shower lined up later this month.

The Orionids Meteor Shower is expected to peak on October 21-22, and will produce up to 20 meteors per hour - making it much easier to see!
